item.title: Richard Steiner, Producer of Broadway Hits, Dies at 69
item.description: Mr. Steiner worked a broad variety of jobs and was, among other things, a poker champion.
item.author: By WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Review: Kristin Chenoweth, That Perky Performer With the Powerhouse Pipes
item.description: Kristin Chenoweth’s concert show, “My Love Letter to Broadway,” displayed her enthusiasm, playfulness, superb voice and entertaining choice of material.
item.author: By CHARLES ISHERWOOD

item.title: Review: Shakespeare’s Take on the Game of Thrones
item.description: In “Kings of War,” the director Ivo van Hove adapts five history plays into a conflagration of corruption, factionalism and political viciousness.
item.author: By BEN BRANTLEY

item.title: London Has a Queen of the Night (From New Jersey)
item.description: Amy Lamé has been appointed Night Czar of London and will create a plan to develop the city’s nighttime industries.
item.author: By ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Tuesday Night’s Literal Showstoppers: Clinton and Trump
item.description: Many New York plays, musicals and operas will take election night off, as audiences are likely to want prime seats for the biggest spectacle: the election.
item.author: By MICHAEL COOPER and MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Kristen Anderson-Lopez, ‘Frozen’ Songwriter, at Home
item.description: The Grammy award winner lives with her husband and frequent collaborator, Robert Lopez, and their children in Brooklyn.
item.author: By JOANNE KAUFMAN

item.title: Molly Ringwald Has Advice to Give and a Role to Match
item.description: The actress talks about preparing for the stage version of “Terms of Endearment” and about her penchant for giving advice.
item.author: By ELISABETH VINCENTELLI

item.title: Review: The Jobs Are Gone in ‘Sweat.’ So Are People’s Hopes.
item.description: In Lynn Nottage’s latest play, the bonds among working-class friends and family unravel as the local economy falls apart.
item.author: By CHARLES ISHERWOOD

item.title: Theater Listings for Nov. 4-10
item.description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

item.title: Lending a Hand (and Fingers, and Fingertips) to Myths
item.description: Akram Khan’s choreography informs “Chotto Desh,” in which an exchange between a man and a youth summons stories Mr. Khan heard from his grandparents.
item.author: By ROSLYN SULCAS
